messageBody:
> From: Johannes Link [mailto:john.link@...]
>
> > > Sometimes the (public) contract cannot be made sufficiently
> > > strong beforehand. Especially when the objects and interfaces
> > > are in the midst of evolving.
> >
> > They can be made solid enough. I myself also do iterative
> > development. I work toward the usage of the component
> before I focus
> > on 100% functionality.
>
> [...]
>
> > interface Store
> > {
> > void store(String key, Object val);
> > Object retrieve(String key);
> > void remove(String key);
> > }
> >
> > That interface is enough to know how to use the object store.
>
> So what are your "solid enough" contracts? How do you find
> those contracts by looking at nothing but an interface definition?


I start there. However, there are some questions that need to be
answered when looking at this specific interface.

What happens if I store an object with a key value that already
exists? Is there an exception to be thrown, or does it silently
overwrite the value there.

The interface above suggests that the object is silently overwritten.
I would likely change the contract of the interface to introduce the
exception. I would also add javadocs to describe that contract in plain
english.

Next question is does the retrieve() method remove the object from the
store? The existense of the the remove() method suggests that they
happen
separately. Therefore I add javadocs to clearly state that the
retrieve()
method does not remove the object from the store.

Lastly, we find that a useful method both for testing and dynamic key
selection would suggest that we need a new method to see if a key is
already used. I would likely add that in.

You always have to have somewhere to start. Usually when you design
such a component, you already have a usecase in mind. You test for that
usecase, and make sure that the contracts of that usecase are clearly
stated in the interface.
